course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Inorganic Chemistry I
course.description: This course is designed for students who have taken CHEM 1030 under the four-year degree. Key topics include atomic structure, molecular structure and bonding, structures of simple solids, physical techniques in inorganic chemistry, molecular symmetry, acids and bases, introduction to coordination chemistry, electronic structures and spectra of coordination compounds. For students in the programs under the four-year degree that designate the course as required course/specified elective, or students with approval from the instructor.

reviews.author: No,Thankyou!
reviews.title: 靚龜科
reviews.comment_content:
L1: Molecular structure and bonding (molecular orbital theory)
L2: Acids and Bases (hard soft acid base theory)
L3: Structures of simple solids
L4: Molecular symmetry
L5: Periodicity
L6: Introduction to coordination chemistry

Midterm exam topics covered: MO Theory, acids and bases, structures of simple solids(up to MX type solid).

Final exam topics covered: Inorganic solids(starting from MX2 type solids) to coordination chemistry.
reviews.comment_teaching:
華雄好好人，香港prof，有唔明問佢野，佢好樂意解答，而且你又可以用廣東話問書。華雄英文好標準，相信冇人聽唔明。上堂華雄會問下大家有冇咩問題，不過通常冇人會問，通常啲人都係落堂先出去問。做assignment又會話有唔識或者想要tips就問佢下/email佢，總之華雄好好人啦，上過佢堂就會明。
完左lecture/tutorial，會有videos upload上canvas，但堂上會有啲iPRS嘅題目，通常係簡單mc咁樣，上唔上堂就自己決定（早上9點堂叫人點上呀hi）
reviews.comment_grading:
Original:
Assignment x2 (2x3%)
Quizzes x2 (2x4%)
Mid-term exam (38%)
Final exam (46%)
others (2%)

Adjusted (due to class cancellations):
Mid-term exam (48%)
Assignment 1 (8%)
Quiz 1 (9%)
Assignment 2 (16%)
Final assessment (online test)(19%)

My grade:
Mid-term exam 42/43
Assignment 1 30/30
Quiz 1 11/14
Assignment 2 40/40
Final assessment (online test) 25/32

Final grade= A
reviews.comment_workload:
平時近乎冇workload，係交assignment前/quiz前/midterm前/exam前咪要俾時間去做/溫。
Assignment其實都好簡單，認真做通常幾個鐘就做完。
平時上堂聽得明啲concept，落堂後咪唔洗點樣去溫，反之亦然。

reviews.author: Lucien11
reviews.title: Better than I Imagined
reviews.comment_content:
1. Molecular structure and bonding (MO)
2. Acid and base
3. Structure of simple solids
(Midterm)

4. Molecular symmetry
5. Periodic trends
6. Introduction to coordination chemistry
7. Oxidation and reduction
(Final)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Explanation to basic concepts were clear and easy to follow.
Although the teaching was a bit slow, it's still good enough.

Lecture notes are nicely prepared, you will be able to review all content based on lecture notes even if you have skipped all lectures.

LWH is a responsible teacher, he will host 4 extra tutorials (2 of them are in-class) to help you understand the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
SO GOOD ! :)

Midterm 36%
Final 48%
2*Assignment 2*3%=6%
2*Quiz 2*3%=6%
Others (iPRS, participation) 4%

My score:
Midterm 38/40
Final 54.5/63
Assignment1 30/30
Assignment2 34/34
Quiz1 9/10
Quiz2 10/11
Others 16/18
(Final Grade A+)

Honestly speaking, I didn't expect A+ when I knew I only got 54.5/63 in the final. Because my midterm and two quizzes are not so high to compensate.
reviews.comment_workload:
Small enough.

2*Assignment+2*Quiz only throughout the whole semester.
Each assignment only 5-6 questions, which can be finished quickly.
Quizzes are all MCs, questions are not difficult.

However, I HATE iPRS (wtf!!!!!!), for which I attended almost all lectures.

reviews.author: hw1817
reviews.title: I love Leung Wa Hung!
reviews.comment_content:
1. Molecular structure and bonding (MO)
2. Acid and base
3. Structure of simple solids
4. Molecular symmetry
5. Periodic trends
6. Introduction to coordination chemistry
7. Oxidation and reduction

topic 1-3: midterm
topic 3-7: final (of course, some basic knowledge of topic 1-2 is required)

In my opinion, the most difficult topic is topic 1. It is quite difficult to understand why the MO of some molecules look like this.

Topic 3 requires some 3D sense to visualize where the octahedral/tetrahedral holes are in ccp and hcp structure. You also need to memorize different kind of solid structures and the holes that structure occupies (e.g. rock salt, zinc blende)

For topic 4, you need to do a lot of exercises in order to be used to identify the symmetry elements. That requires your handwork.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think Professor Leung Wa Hung's teaching is very good. He is nice and always explain the concept well, not just reading the ppt. When you ask him questions, he is always ready to provide you a clear explanation and answer. He maybe the best professor I have met in this semester (I am a year one student).
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading policy:
Assignment: 2 x 3% (2 assignments in total)
Quiz: 2 x 3% (2 quizzes in total)
Midterm: 36% (1 h 20 min)
Final: 48% (2 h)
IPRS + Participation: 4%
(participation: you need to answer at least one question that professor has asked in order to get that score)

I have heard that you can get around B normally in this course. To get A range, you should at least over 1 SD. Hence, it is quite difficult for you if you aim A range.

For my scores:

Assignment: 62.5/64 (mean ~54.3)
Quiz: 21/21 (mean ~13.6)
Midterm: 40/40 (mean ~26.3, SD ~ 6)
Final: 59.5/63 (mean ~39, SD ~ 11.72)
iPRS + participation: 14/18 (mean ~11.6)

Luckily, I got an A+.

The cutoff probably like this:
A-: ~85-90
A: 90- ~95
A+: >95
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload depends on what score is your aim. But generally, your workload comes from the 2 assignments (one before midterm and one before final). Nonetheless, the professor gives you plenty of time to finish the assignments. Hence, the workload is not too high.

However, if you aim A range(e.g. A-), you should do a lot of exercises. Those including the questions from lecture notes, problem sets (provided by the professor), tutorial notes and the sources. You know, many people get a poor grade in organic chemistry, so they will work hard in inorganic chemistry...

reviews.author: Leon Donut
reviews.title: This lad knows how to teach
reviews.comment_content: You can probably see the content from other reviews, so I won't repeat it here. I must say that the coverage of knowledge isn't that wide BUT the things he teaches can be quite deep sometimes and you would need to be extra focused during lecture; I have tried multiple times when I literally looked away for few seconds and came back not knowing what was going on.
reviews.comment_teaching: A for amazing my friends. Professor Lin teaches chemistry in the most intuitive way possible; this man literally compared molecules to people with different personalities. It was one of the very few courses that I was genuinely excited about in my first semester at HKUST. His teaching style is basically showing his PPT slides and making notes on them using his mouse, which is a very good way to teach chemistry in my opinion, because it actually allows students to understand step by step - instead of just memorizing some reactions or molecules. The only negative is his accent - it can take a while to understand his accent, but once you get used to it, you'd be fine. Also, just a note, while some people prefer asking questions during lecture time, I suggest that you don't, because sometimes he wants to finish a certain section in time and doesn't answer your questions in full details, so it would be better to save them for another time (ex. the weekly Q&A session).
reviews.comment_grading: I remember how I almost cried after seeing my 56% on mid-term - his exams are certainly not easy and require a real understanding of the material, not just pure memorization. With the two assignments averaging at 80% and the final at 70%, I managed to scratch an A-. This man cares more about students learning than their grades so the curve is pretty nice. Just ask him after lectures if you do have questions and you will do just fine.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost no workload apart from the two assignments. But please take my advice to study at least an hour each week so that you know what is going on. If you choose to ignore any of the lectures, you will most likely suffer when you listen to the next one, because many things are built on each other.

reviews.author: C8H9NO2
reviews.title: An excellent course!
reviews.comment_content:
Ch1 Introduction and Atomic structure
Ch2 Molecular structure and bonding
Ch3 Structures of simple solids (Midterm↑/Final↓)
Ch4 Acids and bases
Ch5 Molecular symmetry
Ch6 An introduction to coordination
compounds
Ch7 Periodic trends in chemical properties

Reference textbook
“Inorganic Chemistry”, International edition, by Mark Weller et
al., OUP (2018)
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Leung is a really good instructor. He explains everything clearly and highlights those parts that will be tested in exam, which is helpful. It's worth it to attend lectures and I highly recommend it because it makes differences between you and your classmates if you pay attention in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
They revised the assessment scheme at the end of the semester.

Midterm exam 48%
Assignment 1 8%
Quiz 1   9%
Assignment 2  16%
Final assessment 19%

Here's my situation:
Midterm exam 42/45 mean 27.5
Assignment 1 29/30 mean 26.1
Quiz 1 13/14 mean 7.8
Assignment 2 38/40 mean 29.7
Final assessment 28/32 mean 21.7

I got A+ at the end, so I'm not sure about how good the grading was. But in general, this is a good grade course from other people's comments and reviews.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload for this course is not the heaviest one, only exams, quiz and two assignments. However, if you want to get good score, it would require effort and time to study. Spending time to finish all assignments, tutorial notes and problems sets is recommended since they are really helpful for preparing exam.

reviews.author: Feibendehaozi
reviews.title: VERY GOOD
reviews.comment_content: Giving a more specific explanation to CHEM1030, and a good introduction to the chemistry major. There is Introduction, Molecular Orbital, and Solid, and Molecular Symmetry and Introduction to Coordination Complex. I strongly recommend its MO teaching, which is incredible.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is trying to explain everything clearly and is very patient to students. He can explain your problem in Cantonese, Mandarin and English.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty good grade. As long as you pay your hard work you will get a satisfying result. As long as you pay your hard work you will get a satisfying result. As long as you pay your hard work you will get a satisfying result.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty small. There are only two assignments and you will understand your things as long as you pay attention to your lecture. But if you have a strong tendency to be a chemist, you should try to research as much as possible.

reviews.author: 33Sigmatropic
reviews.title: enjoyable
reviews.comment_content:
Some parts are challening but most of it is manageable.

1 Introduction and Atomic structure
2 Molecular structure and bonding
3 Structures of simple solids
4 Acids and bases
5 Molecular symmetry
6 An introduction to coordination
compounds

Midterm covers chapter 1-3 excluding chapter 3's solid electronic structure

Final covers chapter 3's solid electronic strucutre and chapter 4-6
reviews.comment_teaching: Great. Prof. Leung's tutorials were very useful, and Prof. Jia was very willing to answer questions (albeit having some difficulty hearing). Overall both professors did a good job explaining the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
OK.

Quiz 1 & 2: 2x4% (8%)
Quiz 3: 5%
Assignments: 2x5% (10%)
Midterm: 32%
Final: 45%

Midterm:
Mean: 23.05 Median: 24
High: 40 Low: 3
Upper Quartile: 30.13 Lower Quartile: 17.88
out of 50

Final:
Mean: 61.34 Median: 63.5
High: 102 Low: 20
Upper Quartile: 79.5 Lower Quartile: 42.5

out of 100 (there was a 2 point bonus)

2 assignments and 3 quizzes. Very manageable.

Additional, optional practice problems are also provided.

reviews.author: letmegohome
reviews.title: Great teaching, but I am totally confused by the content at first.
reviews.comment_content:
 Molecular structure and bonding
 Acids and bases
 Structure of simple solids
 Molecular symmetry
 Introduction to coordination chemistry

I didn't study anything about structure during high school, so I was COMPLETELY confused at first. I didn't understand what those e t a labels mean, I didn't understand how to rank the energy of the molecular orbitals, I didn't understand sooo much about the orbital stuffs and I was pretty desperate at first(especially it seemed like everyone else could get it so quickly and answer the prof's questions actively)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great Professor.
Unlike most Profs in UST, he actually tried his best to teach us. He gave us quizzes, problem sets, tutorials, assignments, etc. All these really helped me to understand the content, and I really appreciate it.
The style of mt and final is similar to that of the quizzes and assignments. As long as you work on them, put in some effort, you will get a decent grade.

reviews.author: 哈爾請食半島
reviews.title: Good
reviews.comment_content:
Molecular diagram
acid and base
Structure of simple solid
Molecular symmetry
Introduction to coordination chemistry

Expected to be able to
1. Demonstrate comprehensive and well-founded knowledge of structure and bonding theories relevant to inorganic complex.
Describe and rationalise structure of simple inorganic solids.
Rationalise the stability of inorganic compounds using concepts of acids and bases
Assign molecular point groups and recognise the importance of molecular symmetry in chemistry
Understand the structure of coordination compounds
reviews.comment_teaching: He is good professor because he explains in detail concept. Also, he requires all of the student fully understand the concept. You can ask him question if you have any problems. You may also make appointment with him to ask questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term
Final exam
Quizzes
Assignments
Oral exam (for student in online mode)
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite hard because there are 4 set assignment to do and some quizzes you need to do, but quizzes are quite easy.
Also, you need to fully understand the concept because it can help you to get high mark in this course. Work hard is a way to good grade.

reviews.author: Jump Mushroom
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 Introduction and Atomic structure
Chapter 2 Molecular structure and bonding
Chapter 3 Structures of simple solids
Chapter 4 Acids and bases
Chapter 5 Molecular symmetry
Chapter 6 An introduction to coordination compounds
Chapter 7 Periodic trends in chemical properties

Due to classes cancelation, the part of compounds naming was removed.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Leung is a nice person, he presented the concepts clearly. He also encouraged students to raise questions in class or send him emails to clarify concepts. He also spent some time to explain some hard concepts and prepared quite a number of examples and tutorial questions which enhanced our study.
reviews.comment_grading:
Original grading scheme
Midterm - 38%
Final exam - 46%
Quiz - 2x4%
Assignment - 2x3%
Others - 2%

New grading scheme
Quiz 1 - 9%
Assignment 1 - 8%
Assignment 2 -16%
Midterm - 48%
Final assessment - 19%

My grades:
Quiz - 10/14 (Mean 7.8/14)
Assignment 1 - 30/30 (Mean 26.1/30)
Assignment 2 - 39/40 (Mean 29.7/40)
Midterm - 39/43 (Mean 27.5/43)
Final assessment - 22/32 (Mean 21.7/32)

Overall grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: Relatively speaking this course doesn't have a heavy workload. Only one quiz, two assignments, one midterm and one online final assessment. Originally there was no final assessment but final exam, also quiz two was canceled. The assignments could help us to understand the topics more so they worth spending some time to finish.

reviews.author: Connie lolo
reviews.comment_content:
The topics are:
(i) Introduction
(ii) Molecular Structures and Bonding
(iii) Acids and bases
(iv) Structures of simple solids
(v) Molecular symmetry

(vi) Introduction to coordinatioin chemistry
(vii) Periodic characteristics of compounds

There are lecture vidoes. There is a textbook. The content can be found from textbook. Some are related to lab-work.
Textbook is “Inorganic Chemistry”, 6thedition, by Mark Weller et al., OUP (2014)

Reference books: “Inorganic Chemistry”, 4thedition, by C. E. Housecroft and A. G. Sharpe, Pearson (2012)
“Inorganic Chemistry”, 3rd/4thedition, by Gary Miessler and D. A. Tarr, Pearson
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is excellent and nice. His teaching is clear. Lecture videos are provided. We can feel free to ask him any questions. The concept taught is clear. However he taught very fast. And sometimes he tells jokes and have Chinese ascent. The powerpoint is clear, some is quoted from textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is fair. There is iPRS system that can slightly let you score higher. Assignments and quiz occupy little weighting.
Assignment: 5%
Quiz: 5%
Mid term: 40%
Exam: 50%

my result
mid-term: mean
exam: above mean
final grade: B
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not heavy. Two quizzes and two assignments only.

reviews.author: vaporeon_nagisa
reviews.title: A great instructor and a great course
reviews.comment_content:
Molecular Structure and Bonding
Acids and Bases
Structures of Simple Solids
Molecular Symmetry
Introduction to Coordination Chemistry
Periodic Characteristics of Compounds

The amount of content is adequate and not difficult to understand. I would say that molecular symmetry might be the most challenging topic of the course, but it is still comprehensible.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Leung is a great instructor. He talks using simple language so that students are not confused by terms they never heard of. He is also helpful and responds quickly to questions. After class, he is very patient when answering students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments 2*3%
Quizzes 2*4%
Mid-term exam 38%
Final exam 46%
Others (presumably iPRS) 2%

My stats:
Mid-term mean = 36.3/57; I got 56.5/57
Final exam mean = 46.4/75; I got 73/75
Overall = around 96% A+
reviews.comment_workload: There is very little workload. The quizzes are in the form of 14-15 MCs and light revision suffices to tackle the questions. The assignments only contain a few long questions and do not take much time to finish. It also helps with the revision as well.

reviews.author: holymama
reviews.title: Year1 比某IRE大神拉入去送死後感
reviews.comment_content:
Molecular orbital
Ligand group orbital
acid and base (Bronsted, Lewis, Hard soft)
Structure of simple solids (7 crystal systems, lattice energy, semiconductors)
Molecular symmetry (Group theory, IR spectrum, Raman spectroscopy, vibration mode)
Introduction to coordination chemistry (geometry, isomerism, transitional metals)
Some basic periodic trends
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Leung really nice, he teaching was really really good (maybe due to he is a local prof).
During final exam, he even gave us a few minutes to read the paper, and ask him questions if you do not understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
As this course was taught by Wah Hung, it had an extremely good grade
Midterm mean:36.3/57
Final mean: 46.4/75

I got 42/57 and 52.5/75 for midterm and final, all full mark in assignment , almost full mark on 2 quizzes and finally get a B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload at all, all you need to do is just 2 hw and regular revision. but as prof Leung said, most of the advanced topic will be covered in CHEM 3220.
A Periodic table will be given during midterm and final exam. (Seems 3220 won't given, so better spend some time on winter sem to memorize the whole periodic table)

reviews.author: Hyeri
reviews.comment_content:
成科就係講orbital s p d...
之前讀到呢方面如果唔太惦可能有d辛苦

考試有唔少送分題要把握好，唔好因為assignment淺而以為呢科好易，難起上黎都唔係講少

呀Lin教書係書係點？唔駛解釋啦掛
最好笑係佢可以再次推翻自己講過嘅野，notes D graph成日有錯，唔好中伏
reviews.comment_grading:
Chem course入面，grade真係算靚
mean去到B range
reviews.comment_workload:
好易做嘅assignment，只要有個好隊友就ok，就算冇隊友carry，都可以快快手做完
拉把可以借到書，answer有另外一本，記得借埋，new version 數量有限，要借就早d

reviews.author: 綿綿頭上飛花
reviews.title: Feels like CHEM5210
reviews.comment_content:
Ch1 Introduction and Atomic structure
Ch2 Molecular structure and bonding
Ch3 Structures of simple solids
(Midterm↑/Final↓)
Ch4 Acids and bases
Ch5 Molecular symmetry
Ch6 An introduction to coordination
compounds
Ch7 Periodic trends in chemical properties

As Prof.Lin is a big fan of MO, he uses MO to explain a lot of concepts -- even for bond stretching in ch5. You have to follow his mindset in order to read the ppt or do the final paper. Whats more is that he uses structure from Journal paper to test your understanding. It feels like he is teaching us as if a PG student. The contents he taught are really deep. Sometimes even beyond the textbook.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Lin have his own special way to "encourage" students to attend his classes. I guess one of the methods is by uploading ppt with only pictures, with literally no words. He loves to annotate during zoom lesson, you will end up with a screen full with his annotations. He has a unique style of teaching, you need to spend time rethinking about the things he said in the lecture to understand what he wants from us. The parts that he stress or began to get hyper during class are the parts he thinks that are important. He is actually really passionate in teaching and replies email very fast. Tho he only give comments on the concepts to your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% Assignment 1
5% Assignment 2
45% Midterm
45% Final Exam

Prof.Lin said that he will still check on our attendances and might deduct marks for students who skipped all classes. But I am not sure if he did so at last.
reviews.comment_workload: The 2 assignments are submitted before midterm and final. Answers are released the day after. Problem sets and sample papers are also provided. The workload is okay tho you really need to spend time understanding what Prof. Lin teaches. Textbook are sometimes not helpful  as what Prof.Lin mentioned might not even be covered in textbook.

reviews.author: gazelle
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction and Atomic structure
2. Molecular structure and bonding
3. The structures of simple solids
4. Acids and bases
5. Molecular symmetry
6. An introduction to coordination compounds
7. Periodic trends in chemical properties

Midterm covers 1-3 only, whereas final exam covers 4-7. Final exam is not accumulative.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Some people said Professor Lin is a humorous person that it is fun to attend his lecture. To me, the jokes he tells are not fun at all -- his lecture makes me feel sleepy instead because of his mono-tone. His unappealing lecture could be reflected by the attendance rate. When you go into the classroom, you will realise that only ~50-60% of students attend his lecture. I attended his lecture mostly just because I don't want to have attendance points deducted!!! If possible, I would skip most of his lecture and self-learn from YouTube videos.

The good thing is that he explains the sample papers thoroughly and logically, clarifying our misconceptions. (TBH a few exam questions are highly similar to those appeared in SPs.)
reviews.comment_grading:
My score

Assignment 1: 89/104  (mean ~85% I guess)
Assignment 2: 94/100  (mean ~80% I guess)
Midterm: 55/100  (mean 59.66, sd 17.16)
Final exam: 55/100  (mean 54.52, sd 17.24)
Attendance: 2 points deducted (FML!!! Throughout the whole semester I only missed ≤ 3 lectures & you deduct me 2 points????!!!)

Overall score: 56.48/100
(~2% below mean I guess)

Final grade: B-

Grading is pretty good IMO. I studied both exams the night right before. Such preparations were merely enough for me to pass the exams -- lots of misconceptions were still not clarified. I thought my performance only deserves a C+, but in the end I received a lenient B-. If I used the same way of studying in Org Chem, I would probably end up a C grade!!!
reviews.comment_workload: Workload depends largely on your goal. Getting everything around mean would give you a B-. If you aim at A range, you should make sure you understand everything well before exams because exam questions are quite tricky. (If you have experienced the torturing CHEM 1030 final exam, then you would know why did I say that.)

reviews.author: torterral_Tsui
reviews.title: Quite a good course if you attend the class
reviews.comment_content:
The first half of the semester (Sept + Oct) covered molecular orbitals and solid-state chemistry while the second half (Nov) covered Lewis acid & bases and also stereochemistry.

For the MOs, of course you need to learn how to draw them.
The most important new thing is the ligand group orbitals, which describe groups of surrounding atoms by 'in phase' and 'out of phase' combinations. The key to master LGOs in this course is to know how to project the LGO to a single orbital (knowing the shape). The number of LGOs is exactly the number of surrounding atoms.
The second would be hybridization, introduced in 1030. Just knowing that if the energies of the s and p are close enough and they have the same geometry they would hybridize will be more than enough.

Solid state chemistry is rather easy in this course, there are several common structures (like ccp bcc hcp sc) in the course, make sure you understand them. If you don't, memorize them. Count and draw the ions and holes several times while studying, try to think about why there is a hole instead of memorizing the position of the hole.

For Lewis acid and base, you need to know several things, including what is meant by Lewis AB, factors affecting solubility and stability of AB adducts. You may also want to know how to illustrate AB adducts properly. Bronsted-lowry AB are also tested so be prepared.
For your reference, Bronsted-lowry acid refers to proton donor while Lewis acid refers to electron acceptor.

Stereochemistry is the most challenging. This course includes point groups in symmetry and coordinations.
Point groups may seem difficult, because you cannot memorize all of them. There are several 'bigger' classification, namely linear, low symmetry, C, D and TOI. Classifying molecules to these groups may help assign point groups.
Normal modes are more difficult but may be easier as long as you recognize that the number of stretching nodes are the same as the number of sigma bonds. The rest is like LGO projections.
Isomerism: high school stuff. They ask to list out all geometrical isomers and enantiomers, very easy anyways.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Lin teaches well, I guess?

He teaches in an interactive way, I never feel bored in his class. However for some difficult or abstract stuff he can't explain them well. I guess it's a kind of sense? Example: What are hard acid --> You touch the atom its so hard.

Well indeed, metal ions on the lefter side of the periodic table are harder as they have high charge density. You think of a soft acid of having a 'bouncy electron cloud'.

The point is if you think like what he does then it is great, but if you cannot follow him then you probably need to revise or seek help from the ta. Try your best to think like Lin.

Nicest TA i've ever seen (ZhangZ). I sent him an email the evening asking for some help, he replied me the night at 10pm with all those software drawn pictures and paragraph long USEFUL replies. Really nice.

Lin will sometimes do questions wrongly, tell him if he did.
reviews.comment_grading:
I get pretty good scores in both exams and the assignments so I can't really talk about the grading.
Good grade, I guess?


HW: several %
Midterm & Final: remaining half-half
Lottery attendence: Unlucky guys will be deducted marks

*The prof. won't upload any marks to canvas.*

Exam format: some MCs, some short questions. If you know then you know, if you don't then you don't.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you attended class and understood things already you don't really need to study so hard. Just chill.

If you did NOT attend the lecture, the powerpoint will suck and you cannot revise anything but to watch the videos. Only by listening to what Lin says will the ppt be useful.

Past paper provided, but as ppt slide format discussed in class. No service to those who don't come to class or watch videos.

reviews.author: LukaModric
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction and Atomic structure
2. Molecular structure and bonding
3. The structures of simple solids
4. Acids and bases
5. Molecular symmetry
6. An introduction to coordination compounds
7. Periodic trends in chemical properties
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Lin is so cute and funny in the way he presents the concept.
Prof. Lin is so nice that he is willing to answer your questions.
Sample midterm and final will not be uploaded into canvas.
Lecture video is available.
However, Prof. Lin's exam is known to be more difficult than Prof. Leung's.

Final exam: 46%

Assignment 2: 5%
Attendance Deduction
Midterm quite late: 9 Nov at 8:15am

Midterm
Full Mark: 100
Mean: 59.66
SD: 17.16

reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy.
Not much things to remember.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.title: Like a 4000+ Course
reviews.comment_content:
Before Mid-Term:

Metallic Ionic Structures
Coordination No.
Molecular Orbital Theory

After Mid-Term:

Lewis Acids/Bases
Point-Group Theory, Mulliken Symbols (strong spatial senses are VERY important)
Optical and Geometrical Isomerism of Metal-Ligand Compounds
Properties of Inorganic Main Group Compounds
Principle of Semi-Conductors
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although Dr. Lin does not teach really well, he is a very committed teacher and scientist. He is amiable and compassionate to youngsters, treating everyone as his child.

He is also the Head of Chemistry Department, and very eager to help you even with your private and relationship issues.

He is the kindest teacher I have ever met at UST.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 5% x 2 = 10%
Mid-Term: 44%
Final: 46%
Maximum Deduction of 5 marks for Absence

He randomly chose a number of students on his computer and asked them to record their attendance with him every recess, like what he did when teaching CHEM 1030.

The rate of attendance was very low, about 20% on average. Probably, students thought that his lessons were too unappealing.

The exam marks were so “secret”.

For the Mid-Term's, he just displayed them for a while during the lesson. If you were absent without sickness, he refused to let you know your mark.

I was absent for the lesson when he displayed our marks. I asked my classmate on the following day whether he saw my mark, he said he could not see it. I got to email Dr. Lin and lied to him I was sick that day, after which he was barely willing to let me know my mark.

For the Final's, we were not even allowed to know. I was below mean (fairly low) by 10.5 marks in the Mid-Term Exam and did not know my mark of the Final Exam.

I was eventually given a generous C+ .
reviews.comment_workload:
The lecture materials were much more difficult than those of Inorganic Chemistry II (Year 2 Spring) and even Physical Chemistry II (Year 3 Spring).

This course resembles a 4000+ course more than a 2200+.

reviews.author: Brownpanda
reviews.comment_content:
主要係教molecular orbital, acid and base, molecular symmetry同coordination
Molecular orbital相對比較難理解，可能要花多啲時間，其他topic ge話都唔會話太難
考試較為着重理解多於背誦
但係教ge嘢比較少，好似好多topic都冇cover到
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Leung上堂唔係照ppt讀都算okay嘅，如果上堂有認真聽考試唔會話好難。起唔到身上堂都唔緊要，因為佢會up lecture videos，考試之前睇番就得。
Lecture notes唔會話好多頁，算精簡，有時可能要抄吓筆記，寫低啲佢係notes冇寫ge explanation，但一般唔會考notes冇ge嘢
但有時問佢嘢，佢會有啲hea，會答你依樣唔會考就算
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading中等，攞mean大概B-/B，聽講攞D/C-/C ge人唔多，大部份人都集中係C+/B-/B/B+，所以唔會話好差(係chem course嚟講)
但如果要去到a range ge話就要考得好啲(高超過一個SD)
reviews.comment_workload:
有兩份assignments，兩個quizzes，然後midterm final
Assignments同quizzes都係題數唔多ge，而且佔ge percentage都好少，主要都係用嚟温書，所以通常會係midterm final前
建議assignments認真做，因為都midterm final考得似assignments

reviews.author: Kemist
reviews.title: OK course
reviews.comment_content:
1. Molecular structure and bonding (MO)
So fricking hard to comprehend in the first place, but after a lot of digestion, it is still hard to comprehend, so don't even try.

2. Acid and base
with the help of MO theory, you will finally understand a lot of phenomena, but you need to know what is happening in MO theory first, which is impossible

3. Structure of simple solids
the first half is ok, just structure and calculation, but the second half is hard to understand and a lot to memorize

4. Molecular symmetry
very fun

5. Periodic trends
like octat rule, the biggest lie in chemistry

6. Introduction to coordination chemistry
very basic so not so hard

7. Oxidation and reduction
a lot of overlapping with physical chem may be hard to comprehend too, but as long as you know how to calculate it's ok.

mt covers topic 1, 2 and a little bit of topic 3
final covers topic 3-7, which is a lie, as the concepts in topic 1 and 2 are included too.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is ok, Wa Hung is willing to answer questions, which slows down the progress by a lot. However, sometimes what he and is not what I ask, which is a little bit annoying
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is ok but disappointing for me

Midterm 36%
Final 48%
2*Assignment 2*3%=6%
2*Quiz 2*3%=6%
Others (iPRS, participation) 4%

My score:
Midterm 37.5/40 (mean ~26.3, SD ~ 6)
Final 54.5/63 (mean ~39, SD ~ 11.72)
Assignment1 29/30
Assignment2 32.5/34
Quiz1 5/10 (below mean bruh)
Quiz2 8/11
iPRS and stuff 16/18
Ended up with an A, saw someone in the review got similar scores in exams but got an A+, should have revised for the quizzes :")
reviews.comment_workload:
very little workload, only two hw in one semester
Make notes for the exams and revise is enough for an a range

reviews.author: vicknt
reviews.comment_content: I would say the arrangement of content is reasonable, and it doesnt really ask to memorize a lot once the student comprehend the concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: prof LEUNG is helpful and kind, always replies the emails in time and explains clearly. personally i think he is the best prof i have met this semester, however  i feel he compromises a lot in many aspects.
reviews.comment_grading: not quite strict, on the contrary, a little bit excessively loose.
reviews.comment_workload: comparatively light compared to org.chem which might results from some overlap with the knowledge in previous courses.

reviews.author: RichardY
reviews.comment_content: The content is appropriate but not particularly interesting (and it is pretty abstract at some points). I suggest it has missed some elements on how the knowledge in this course can be applied to real life circumstances. The main content includes MO theory, acid-base theory, solid structure and property, band theory, molecular shape and symmetry, IR spectroscopy and finally crystal field theory. If you have a strong background in introductory level physical and inorganic chemistry concepts (bondings e.g. MO, coulombic force, intermolecular force; structure e.g. VSEPR; thermodynamics etc.), then you would find this course not too difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Leung is a knowledgeable, responsible and humble teacher. Nice experience to be a student under his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: I got the highest score in both midterm and final (overall = 94.3%) so it is not very convincing for me to say whether the grade is good or not. However, one of my friends got an A for (overall ~ 80.9%) and so the grade should be pretty good. The course overall mean as calculated from canvas grade details is 63.3%. S.D. for such a normal and rather big class size course should be around 13-15%.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate from my experience up to this stage. A comparison to CHEM2110 (since I was taking both in the same semester) would be that CHEM2210's workload is much lower (for aiming A+). A midterm and a final + 2 quizzes + 2 assignments.

reviews.author: bsbsbsbs
reviews.title: NOT SURVIVOR BIAS
reviews.comment_content:
[before midterm]
Hard, but not very hard.
It’s easy in a sense that it is all MO stuff, everything is MO diagram and mixing and similar stuff
But It’s hard in a way that the marking scheme is very bad. It often just assumes students to follow certain rules, for example, when drawing a MO diagram, they expect you to always put Antibonding at a higher energy level than non-bonding, which is not always true. But they won’t let you explain that you’ve considered other factors and that you’re wrong for this question, and the subsequent question, and the subsequent question too -they just all agree to one convention for the ease of teaching and grading and just stick to that.
——
Totally not recommended, if you do have to take this for requirements, don’t take it with hope and expectations.
After all, this course is not a for-learning course, it’s more a grade-getting course. Or else the prof should have made the exams open book just like ANY other good universities do (literally just name any, I can do that right off my mind rn: Imperial, MIT, Oxford…) oh, and also, it tests factual recall to a certain degree, get ready to brute memorise the coordination number of crystal structure of some salts
reviews.comment_teaching:
Fair.
But he almost never goes to the main point and just has so much bs that half the class couldn’t bare it and chose to skip his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Dunno yet, will update later.
But as mentioned, the grading of papers is horrendous.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair.
A few assignments and a few quizzes.
But this is certainly one of the most overrated CHEM courses in USTspace so I’ll do my best to balance out other biased af reviews, thank me later

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
Molecular Structure and Bonding
Solid States
Acids and Bases
Molecular Symmetry
Coordination Chemistry
Periodicity

The topics build on the content in CHEM 1010 and CHEM 1030. Moderate difficulty level.
reviews.comment_teaching: He does not explain the topics clearly at all. Often skips some parts of the lectures. The lectures are recorded and uploaded online, which is good because it's at 9 am, but still not helpful. Revision for exams is almost impossible because the lecture notes he uploads are completely useless. Most of them have only pictures and diagrams with no text information to explain them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 5% x 2 = 10%
Midterm: 44%
Final: 46%
Attendance: Deduction

Assignments are not very difficult, we have 1 week to complete them. The mean is very high and many people get full marks.

Midterm and final have MCQ and short questions. They never released the mean/SD of the midterm or the final, and no paper checking for either.

I got 100 in assignment 1, 50.5 in midterm, 83 in assignment 2, 39 in final.
Total 48.3 = grade C+.
reviews.comment_workload: 2 assignments, not very difficult, but takes a long time. Midterm has only 2 topics, final has many. Revision is very difficult without any proper lecture notes.

reviews.author: Demeter0321
reviews.title: Kinda disappointed
reviews.comment_content:
The content matches my expectations. It is a higher level course that requires a deeper understanding of the subject. You can get high marks if you memorize facts well enough. You will do fine if your DSE biology was good.

Outline:
Friday, 03/09 Introduction of Biochemistry
Monday, 06/09 Amino Acids
Friday, 10/09 Protein Structure I
Monday, 13/09 Protein Structure II
Friday, 17/09 Protein Function and Evolution
Monday, 20/09 Protein Technology
Friday, 24/09 Enzymes & Enzymatic Reactions
Monday, 27/09 Enzyme Kinetics I
Monday, 04/10 Enzyme Kinetics II
Friday, 08/10 Enzyme Regulation
Monday, 11/10 Enzyme Cofactors & Coenzymes
Friday, 15/10 Course Review / Tutorial / Quiz
Tuesday, 19/10 Mid-term Examination (7:00 pm – 8:30 pm, CYT-LTL)
Friday, 22/10 Lipids
Monday, 25/10 Biomembranes
Friday, 29/10 Carbohydrates I
Monday, 01/11 Carbohydrates II
Friday, 05/11 Nucleic Acids
Monday, 08/11 Chromatin Organization
Friday, 12/11 DNA Replication
Monday, 15/11 DNA Repair and Recombination
Friday, 19/11 Transcription and RNA Processing
Monday, 22/11 Protein Synthesis
Friday, 26/11 Genetic Engineering
Monday, 29/11 Course Review / Tutorial / Quiz
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor always ends the lesson 30 minutes earlier than scheduled. Unprofessional. Was expecting him to explain more but he said we should study on our own because this is not a beginner's course.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. No homework whatsoever. 1 midterm, 1 final, 2 quizzes. You might want to do more extra reading/exercise to help with memorizing the content.
